description:
Lichtheimia ramosa is a species of fungus belonging to the order Mucorales, which is a group of fungi commonly known as "bread molds" or "pin molds." This species is characterized by its branched, tree-like (ramose) sporangiophores, which are the structures that bear the spore-containing sporangia.

Lichtheimia ramosa is considered a saprophytic fungus, meaning it obtains its nutrients by decomposing organic matter in the environment. It is commonly found in soil, decaying plant material, and other organic substrates.

The fungus produces spherical sporangia at the tips of the branched sporangiophores, which release spores that can aid in the dispersal and propagation of the species. Lichtheimia ramosa is known to exhibit dimorphism, meaning it can grow in both a filamentous, hyphal form and a yeast-like form, depending on environmental conditions.

This species is of interest in the field of mycology, as it can play a role in various ecological processes and may have potential applications in biotechnology or medicine, although its specific roles and uses are still being investigated by researchers.
